Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Undergraduate Research Experiences in DNA-based discoveries in Hawaii's biodiversity
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to the University of Hawaii at Manoa (UHM), located in Honolulu, HI, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2016-2018. Participants will take advantage of high-throughput DNA sequencing and phylogenetic methods to study the identity and origins of Hawaii's native, endemic and invasive organisms. REU participants will be mentored by a diverse faculty from the departments of Botany, Biology, and Microbiology, the Hawaii Natural Energy Institute at UHM, and Kapi'olani Community College. A guest mentor from the Los Alamos National Laboratory will also participate for one week each summer. The REU experience will begin with one week of laboratory training in molecular, microbiology and genomic techniques, to allow students with limited higher-level biology background or no research experience to participate. A diverse group of REU participants from a variety of institutions and backgrounds will be recruited. Funds will provide for on-campus housing to support students who must relocate to participate. The REU experience will be enhanced by weekly workshops to explore graduate school, scientific communication, responsible conduct of research, and culminate in a scientific poster presentation by each participant.

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will be exposed to career options which utilize skills they learned in working with DNA and bioinformatic tools. Students will learn how research is conducted, and may present their work at scientific conferences.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences) will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine student career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://manoa.hawaii.edu/biodiversity-REU, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Stuart Donachie at donachie@hawaii.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Stephanie Kraft-Terry at kraft2@hawaii.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This REU was designed to enable participants, upon completion, to apply what they learned and the experience gained to propose hypotheses, conduct scientific research and draw appropriate conclusions, apply laboratory and literature analysis skills to answer scientific questions, present their research findings in a professional manner in both oral and written formats, identify careers that align with their interests, and outline a path to achieve their career goals.

Thirty-four students from over 1400 applicants from non-PhD granting institutions, community and tribal colleges, and research institutions separated by almost 8,000 miles, were hosted in laboratories of 12 faculty mentors at the University of Hawai?i in summers between 2016 and 2020. Before undertaking projects, participants were trained in laboratory safety, and basic laboratory practices they would use in DNA-based research, plus hands-on electron microscope sample preparation and viewing. Participants met weekly with the program?s PI, co-PI, mentors and others in the academic community to discuss their projects, career opportunities, and to engage in topical discussions about their fields, including training and discussions about ethics in science. Weekly meetings focused on developing the poster that each participant would present to their peers, experts, and community members at the end-of-summer event for all undergraduates engaged in research or creative work.

Since the project emphasized experience with and utility of DNA sequencing in the biological sciences, participants typically undertook a project whose main questions or hypotheses rested upon extraction of DNA from a sample or range of samples, and approaches to sequence part or all of that DNA, followed by computer-based analyses of the sequence data. Some focused on one gene, or ?barcode?, to investigate diversity or evolutionary history in a species or multiple species. Others investigated the nature and number of species in a sample, such as 'bacterial diversity', or sequenced the complete genome of a single species. Such skills are at the core of contemporary and emerging biological fields.

Participation in our REU had positive outcomes for the participants: feedback referred to the lifechanging effect of undertaking scientific research, the impact on their education and professional career development, and that subsequent opportunities and experiences would not have been possible without this REU. Most of the participants have gone on to Graduate School, while some have also been funded through the National Science Foundation?s Graduate Research Fellowship Program.

Kayla Hiura discovered a new Dickeya (Bacteria) species in Ulupo?o marsh. A manuscript formally describing this new species will be submitted for publication.

Brittany Lawson discovered two new Bacteria species in lava caves of Hawai?i. Manuscripts formally describing these new species will be submitted for publication.

Elizabeth Winnicki contributed to a project on larval morphology and DNA barcodes in Hawaiian stomatopods. A manuscript describing this work will be submitted for publication.
